messages.subject: Re: Yari type
messages.msgSnippet: A four-sided, blunt (rounded) tipped yari could be called an ichio-yari. ... From: Ron Hartmann To: TOKEN ; nihontostudy ; nihonto@yahoogroups.com Sent:
messages.messageBody:
A four-sided, blunt (rounded) tipped yari could be called an ichio-yari.
----- Original Message -----
From: Ron Hartmann
To: TOKEN ; nihontostudy ; nihonto@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Thursday, May 05, 2005 12:05 PM
Subject: Yari type


Hi All -

Can anyone tell me the correct (accepted today) name for a yari I'm making a record sheet on today? To describe it, it is a stubby, short (4") head, 4-sided yari made with yokote. This one is quite nice and signed by Yokoyama Bizen Sukehira (shinshin-to).

In Kajihara's glossery (p.250) illustrates what I would say is that shape/form, but a number of names are given for it: tanpo yari, te yari, ko-yari, kago yari, mijika-yari.

The mijika-yari elaborates, saying "short, straight yari of 3 to 6 sun." This sounds like what my yari would be but then the other types are simply identified by a name (which I can not translate, other than the ko-yari). Any answer to this?

Can anyone comment on Knutsen's latest publication on pole arms, if it is useful...cost and sources? I've yet to buy a copy and have already forgotten the name of this latest Knutsen publication.

Ron
STL

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Yari type
messages.msgSnippet: There aren t a lot of other choices in English besides the older, very scarce and expensive earlier title by the same author.  It s 40 pounds from:
messages.messageBody:
There aren't a lot of other choices in English besides the older, very scarce and expensive earlier title by the same author. It's 40 pounds from:

http://www.globaloriental.co.uk/book.asp?Title_ID=13

A blade without projections is a su yari. A four-sided spear blade is a ryo-shinogi-yari.


----- Original Message -----
From: Ron Hartmann
To: TOKEN ; nihontostudy ; nihonto@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Thursday, May 05, 2005 12:05 PM
Subject: [nihontostudy] Yari type


Hi All -

Can anyone tell me the correct (accepted today) name for a yari I'm making a record sheet on today? To describe it, it is a stubby, short (4") head, 4-sided yari made with yokote. This one is quite nice and signed by Yokoyama Bizen Sukehira (shinshin-to).

In Kajihara's glossery (p.250) illustrates what I would say is that shape/form, but a number of names are given for it: tanpo yari, te yari, ko-yari, kago yari, mijika-yari.

The mijika-yari elaborates, saying "short, straight yari of 3 to 6 sun." This sounds like what my yari would be but then the other types are simply identified by a name (which I can not translate, other than the ko-yari). Any answer to this?

Can anyone comment on Knutsen's latest publication on pole arms, if it is useful...cost and sources? I've yet to buy a copy and have already forgotten the name of this latest Knutsen publication.

Ron
STL

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Yari type
messages.msgSnippet:
Original posting from Jim ... re Knutsen s polearm book, with link to
Paragon site. Rick From: RCorbin Date: 01/18/05 14:10:23 To:
messages.messageBody:
Original posting from Jim ... re Knutsen's polearm book, with link to
Paragon' site.

Rick

From: RCorbin
Date: 01/18/05 14:10:23
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com; nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Knutsen reprint


If I could also add, a reference to Roald Knutsen other "new" book "
Rediscovering Budo from a Swordsmans Perspective" - although less on
weaponry information as is his Japanese Spears & Polearms - ... it is a
wonderful read and a great reference book on the roots/history and tradition
of Bujutsu & Budo from a person with a wealth of hands-on experience in
Japan of the swordsmans & warrior culture.
with Bibliography, Glossary & Notes

ISBN 1-901903-61-3
Published 2004 - Global Oriental

Rick

-------Original Message-------

From: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Date: 01/18/05 12:23:00
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Subject: [nihontostudy] Knutsen reprint

Someone was asking about when the reprint of Knutsen's book on polearms
would be available. I just got the below in an email from Paragon. Amazon
s price is the same.

Knutsen, Roald & Knutsen, Patricia: JAPANESE SPEARS: POLEARMS AND THEIR USE
IN OLD JAPAN 7 x 9.75", xxvi, 131 pp., 16 b/w plates, 64 pages of b/w
figures, glossary, bibliography, index, cloth, d.j., Kent, 2004.
This fully illustrated study of naginata and yari, the only reference of its
kind in English, records the many variations of spear design from the
ancient period when warrior chieftains settled in Japan from the Asian
mainland, down to the fall of the Tokugawa in 1868 that marked the close of
the feudal period. In addition, it offers the reader valuable insight into
the historical attitude of the Japanese warrior to warfare and examples of
how these often splendid weapons in the bujutsu - the arts of the
battlefield. Item # 30321 ISBN 1901903567 (Global Oriental) Price: $50.00
http://www.paragonbook.com/html/browsesubj/fullcitation.cfm?item=30321

Jim
